stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream defining the look, feel and structure of Course 13 – a surreal, platform-heavy Ice Castle – while brainstorming what Course 14 and 15 should be. He experiments in Blender and in-game with shaders, textures and room shapes, debates boss concepts (Raphael the Raven vs. giant snowman), and discusses overall level ordering and difficulty. Occasional tangents cover emulator problems and a personal haircut mishap.

development_findings.summary: Active production begins on Course 13, envisioned as a gloomy “Ice Castle” full of suspended platforms over abysses, hexagonal room layouts, crystal walls and minimal NPC presence.
Boss ideas are still open: a cinematic Raphael the Raven fight starting on a tower with the moon backdrop, or an alternative rolling-snowman concept where the hat attacks separately.
development_findings.quote: For me, the number one priority when we make a boss is to make sure it's a cool set piece.

development_findings.summary: Visual R&D: Kaze tests layered environment-mapped textures, fog colours and Voronoi-style crystal patterns to achieve high-contrast icy surfaces without obvious tiling.

Course ordering is under review; the craft-materials level (paper, cardboard, glue, origami, googly eyes, etc.) will likely become Course 14, while the Space Casino may shift to 15 to maintain thematic variety.
Design principle reiterated: late-game courses should stay heavily platform-focused; puzzles and mechanics that force waiting (e.g., 30-second day/night cycles) are rejected as “anti-fun”.
development_findings.quote: I don’t think I want puzzles in this. Puzzles are very much against the design of this game.

development_findings.summary: Difficulty ‘index’ spreadsheet is being adjusted so players learn controls progressively and avoid monotony across 30+ levels.
Overworld will be fruit-themed; coins collected in courses are spent on overworld upgrades. Each main course will still contain a retro-pipe side level.
Technical hiccups: memory corruption causes long loads; several emulators crash. Project64 1.6 is the recommended stop-gap, as Parallel and newer PJ64 builds mis-emulate hardware.
development_findings.quote: Right now the game has a lot of issues on a lot of emulators… Project 64 inaccuracies, unfortunately.

context_findings.summary: Kaze views boss fights mainly as visual spectacles rather than gameplay highlights.
context_findings.quote: Boss fights in video games are like zero fun for me… I can only appreciate boss fights as a set piece.

context_findings.summary: He is openly frustrated with emulator inaccuracies and controller quirks, calling Xbox pads “so ass”.
Advocates learning via ChatGPT and disdains low-quality tutorial channels; emphasises the need for strong math intuition in game programming.
Personal anecdote: Zeina accidentally shaved a bald stripe into Kaze’s hair, highlighting their home-life overlap.
context_findings.quote: She had the razor set to 21 mm, took the guard off to clean it, and just kept going – huge bald line right here.

context_findings.summary: Work setup: Kaze streams from a basement office; Zeina now works from her own office, so she rarely appears on-camera.

biobak.summary: Suggested the craft-materials theme and advocated swapping it to Course 14 so the visual pacing works.
biobak.quote: What Biobak said makes sense to me… let's make the paper level Course 14.

biobak.summary: Asked whether late-game courses should be 'gimmicky or very platformy', helping cement the platform-first decision.

zeina.summary: Accidentally botched Kaze’s haircut, illustrating casual partner involvement beyond animation duties.

key_stories.title: Forging the Ice Castle
key_stories.summary: Kaze and chat struggle to nail a distinctive visual identity for Course 13. Early snowy brick tests look bland, so he experiments with hexagonal rooms, crystal walls, fog colours and layered shaders until a higher-contrast crystal scheme begins to emerge.
key_stories.challenge: Create an eerie but readable late-game environment that avoids typical 'snow level' clichés.
key_stories.process: Iterates live in Blender and emulator, tweaking combiners, textures, fog and room shapes; solicits feedback on contrast, tiling and spikes.
key_stories.outcome: A tentative art direction featuring crystal walls, dark recesses and layered environment mapping; still needs refined contrast and boss integration.
key_stories.key_quote: We need to make this castle look good first – colours, then detail – or it won’t hold up against the other levels.

key_stories.title: Paper-Craft Pivot
key_stories.summary: The team had no satisfying idea for Course 15. Brain-storming led to a ‘craft materials’ world of cardboard, glue and googly-eye enemies. Realising the vibe fit better earlier in the game, Kaze decides to shift it to Course 14.
key_stories.challenge: Find a fresh, feasible theme for one of the remaining main courses.
key_stories.process: Chat lists household craft items; Kaze notes each, discusses simple NPCs, and weighs visual workload versus reward.
key_stories.outcome: Craft level locked in (Course 14), with notes for paper NPCs, ruler platforms, confetti storms, etc.
key_stories.key_quote: I’m pretty happy with the craft materials level after this – mostly platforming, a few characters made of paper, very simple dialogue.

key_stories.title: The Haircut Mishap
key_stories.summary: Off-camera, Zeina accidentally shaved a bald stripe into Kaze’s hair by removing the guard mid-trim. He jokes about the aftermath during stream.
key_stories.challenge: Embarrassing grooming accident right before appearing on camera.
key_stories.process: Kaze recounts how Zeina ‘kept going’ after removing the guard, leaving a visible stripe.
key_stories.outcome: He embraces the look on stream, illustrating their laid-back relationship.
key_stories.key_quote: I just had a bald line for half my head the day it happened.

open_questions.topic: Final theme and mechanics for Course 15
open_questions.context: Kaze calls it ‘the last level’ that must be a ‘banger’, but ideas like rainbow reef, night/day swaps or greenhouse remain unresolved.
questions: What core emotion and mechanic do you ultimately want players to feel in Course 15?
Which discarded ideas (dream level, day-night, rainbow road) taught you the most about what you don’t want?
How will Course 15 tie into Yoshi lore or the narrative climax?

open_questions.topic: Boss design for the Ice Castle
open_questions.context: Candidates include Raphael the Raven with a moon cutscene or a rolling snowman head; no final decision yet.
questions: How do you balance nostalgia (Raphael) with surprise for veteran players?
What technical hurdles come with rendering a large Raven on N64 hardware?
What does ‘fun as a set piece’ specifically mean for the fight’s mechanics?

open_questions.topic: Texture & Shader Pipeline on Real Hardware
open_questions.context: Kaze worries about performance (9 ms per three texture layers) and emulator inaccuracies while pushing complex combiners.
questions: How are you validating that the Ice Castle’s layered shaders will run on original N64 without slowdown?
Do you have fallback visuals for low-accuracy emulators?
What tooling or workflow improvements are planned to catch memory corruption earlier?

open_questions.context: On stream, Kaze relies on chat; off-stream collaboration with Biobak, Badub and Zeina is implied but not shown.
questions: How are final calls on themes, art and music made within the core team?
Can you walk us through a recent disagreement and how you resolved it?
What tools (Discord, Trello, etc.) support your remote collaboration?

open_questions.context: Coins will buy ‘overworld upgrades’, but details are vague.
questions: What kinds of upgrades can players purchase and how do they impact gameplay?
How does this system reinforce the fruit-themed overworld narrative?
